Navigating the impact of AI systems in the workplace: strengths and loopholes of the EU AI Act from a labour perspective

This research paper, authored by Chiara Cristofolini and published in the Italian Labour Law e-Journal, critically examines the potential impacts of AI systems within the workplace, specifically focusing on the implications arising from the European Union’s AI Act. The work adopts a labor law perspective, analyzing both the opportunities and risks presented by AI deployment. The paper begins with an introductory overview of AI's rapid advancements and its dual nature as a source of both promise and concern. It then delves into the EU’s regulatory strategy, outlining the objectives and legal foundations underpinning the AI Act. A key focus is the ‘risk-based’ approach, assessing its effects on the utilization of AI systems related to employment. The research scrutinizes the responsibilities of AI system providers, particularly concerning ‘high-risk’ systems, and investigates the obligations placed upon employers who deploy these technologies. Transparency and information requirements are also examined, highlighting both the potential strengths and weaknesses of the current framework. The paper ultimately provides a critical assessment of the EU AI Act’s impact on labor relations, considering the rights and obligations of all stakeholders involved. The research is underpinned by a double-blind peer review process, indicating a rigorous evaluation of the arguments presented. Chiara Cristofolini, an Assistant Professor in Labour Law at the University of Trento, conducted this analysis. The document’s publication in the Italian Labour Law e-Journal suggests a scholarly focus on the legal and ethical considerations surrounding AI’s integration into the workforce. The DOI (https://doi.org/10.6092/issn.1561-8048/19796) provides a permanent link to the research.
